connector.description: Expose WebSocket endpoints using the Atmosphere framework.

camel.sink.endpoint.chunked.name: camel.sink.endpoint.chunked
camel.sink.endpoint.chunked.description: If this option is false the Servlet will disable the HTTP streaming and set the content-length header on the response

camel.sink.endpoint.disableStreamCache.name: camel.sink.endpoint.disableStreamCache
camel.sink.endpoint.disableStreamCache.description: Determines whether or not the raw input stream from Servlet is cached or not (Camel will read the stream into a in memory/overflow to file, Stream caching) cache. By default Camel will cache the Servlet input stream to support reading it multiple times to ensure it Camel can retrieve all data from the stream. However you can set this option to true when you for example need to access the raw stream, such as streaming it directly to a file or other persistent store. DefaultHttpBinding will copy the request input stream into a stream cache and put it into message body if this option is false to support reading the stream multiple times. If you use Servlet to bridge/proxy an endpoint then consider enabling this option to improve performance, in case you do not need to read the message payload multiple times. The http producer will by default cache the response body stream. If setting this option to true, then the producers will not cache the response body stream but use the response stream as-is as the message body.

camel.sink.endpoint.headerFilterStrategy.name: camel.sink.endpoint.headerFilterStrategy
camel.sink.endpoint.headerFilterStrategy.description: To use a custom HeaderFilterStrategy to filter header to and from Camel message.

camel.sink.endpoint.sendToAll.name: camel.sink.endpoint.sendToAll
camel.sink.endpoint.sendToAll.description: Whether to send to all (broadcast) or send to a single receiver.

camel.sink.endpoint.transferException.name: camel.sink.endpoint.transferException
camel.sink.endpoint.transferException.description: If enabled and an Exchange failed processing on the consumer side, and if the caused Exception was send back serialized in the response as a application/x-java-serialized-object content type. On the producer side the exception will be deserialized and thrown as is, instead of the HttpOperationFailedException. The caused exception is required to be serialized. This is by default turned off. If you enable this then be aware that Java will deserialize the incoming data from the request to Java and that can be a potential security risk.

camel.sink.endpoint.useStreaming.name: camel.sink.endpoint.useStreaming
camel.sink.endpoint.useStreaming.description: To enable streaming to send data as multiple text fragments.

camel.sink.endpoint.httpBinding.name: camel.sink.endpoint.httpBinding
camel.sink.endpoint.httpBinding.description: To use a custom HttpBinding to control the mapping between Camel message and HttpClient.

camel.sink.endpoint.bridgeEndpoint.name: camel.sink.endpoint.bridgeEndpoint
camel.sink.endpoint.bridgeEndpoint.description: If the option is true, HttpProducer will ignore the Exchange.HTTP_URI header, and use the endpoint's URI for request. You may also set the option throwExceptionOnFailure to be false to let the HttpProducer send all the fault response back.

camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.name: camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer
camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.sink.endpoint.mapHttpMessageBody.name: camel.sink.endpoint.mapHttpMessageBody
camel.sink.endpoint.mapHttpMessageBody.description: If this option is true then IN exchange Body of the exchange will be mapped to HTTP body. Setting this to false will avoid the HTTP mapping.

camel.sink.endpoint.mapHttpMessageFormUr.name: camel.sink.endpoint.mapHttpMessageFormUrlEncodedBody
camel.sink.endpoint.mapHttpMessageFormUr.description: If this option is true then IN exchange Form Encoded body of the exchange will be mapped to HTTP. Setting this to false will avoid the HTTP Form Encoded body mapping.

camel.sink.endpoint.mapHttpMessageHeader.name: camel.sink.endpoint.mapHttpMessageHeaders
camel.sink.endpoint.mapHttpMessageHeader.description: If this option is true then IN exchange Headers of the exchange will be mapped to HTTP headers. Setting this to false will avoid the HTTP Headers mapping.

camel.sink.endpoint.synchronous.name: camel.sink.endpoint.synchronous
camel.sink.endpoint.synchronous.description: Sets whether synchronous processing should be strictly used, or Camel is allowed to use asynchronous processing (if supported).

camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.laz.name: camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.lazyStartProducer
camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.laz.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.all.name: camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.allowJavaSerializedObject
camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.all.description: Whether to allow java serialization when a request uses context-type=application/x-java-serialized-object. This is by default turned off. If you enable this then be aware that Java will deserialize the incoming data from the request to Java and that can be a potential security risk.

camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.aut.name: camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.autowiredEnabled
camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.aut.description: Whether autowiring is enabled. This is used for automatic autowiring options (the option must be marked as autowired) by looking up in the registry to find if there is a single instance of matching type, which then gets configured on the component. This can be used for automatic configuring JDBC data sources, JMS connection factories, AWS Clients, etc.

camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.htt.name: camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.httpBinding
camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.htt.description: To use a custom HttpBinding to control the mapping between Camel message and HttpClient.

camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.htt.name: camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.httpConfiguration
camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.htt.description: To use the shared HttpConfiguration as base configuration.

camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.hea.name: camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.headerFilterStrategy
camel.component.atmosphere-websocket.hea.description: To use a custom org.apache.camel.spi.HeaderFilterStrategy to filter header to and from Camel message.
